title: For the love of foreign languages
intro: How many languages would you like to speak? Do you agree that "to have another language is to possess a second soul"? Neil and Rob talk about polyglots and teach you some English vocabulary.
this_week_question: The word polyglot comes from Greek and is made up of two parts: poly, which as Rob says, means ‘many’, and ‘glot’. But what does ‘glot’ mean? What is the meaning of the word polyglot ? Is it:
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: feel that you are similar or closely connected to something
nothing except; used to emphasise how strong, pure or powerful a feeling is
spirit or non-physical part of a person which is sometimes believed to continue to exist after death
skill and ability to do something well
working quickly and effectively in an organised way

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I’m Rob.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Bonjour, Rob! Kon’nichi’wa!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Excuse me?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: ¡Hola! ¿Cómo estás?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, OK, I think Neil’s saying ‘hello’ in different languages – French, was it? And then.. Japanese? And… Spanish? Is that right?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: ¡Si, muy bien!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The English are famously slow to learn other languages. But it seems that Rob and I - and of course you - our global audience here at 6 Minute English - are good examples of polyglots – people who speak more than one language, sometimes known as 'superlinguists'. People who speak multiple languages benefit from many advantages, as we’ll be hearing in this programme.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That word polyglot sounds familiar, Neil. Doesn’t the prefix – poly – mean, ‘many’?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s right, like polygon – a shape with many sides.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Or polymath – someone who knows many things.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And speaking of knowing things, it’s time for my quiz question. The word polyglot comes from Greek and is made up of two parts: poly, which as Rob says, means ‘many’, and ‘glot’. But what does ‘glot’ mean? What is the meaning of the word polyglot ? Is it: a) many words?, b) many sounds? or c) many tongues?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, there’s three syllables in ‘polyglot’, Neil, so I reckon it’s b), many sounds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Rob, we’ll find out if that’s right at the end of the programme. But leaving aside the origins of the word, what exactly does being a polyglot involve? British-born polyglot, Richard Simcot speaks eleven languages. Listen to his definition as he speaks to BBC World Service programme, The Documentary:

transcript.author: Richard Simcot
transcript.text: A polyglot for me can be anyone who identifies with that term – it’s somebody who learns languages that they don’t necessarily need for their lives, but just out of sheer enjoyment, pleasure or fascination with another language or culture.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: For Richard, being a polyglot simply means identifying with the idea - feeling that you are similar or closely connected to it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He says polyglots learn languages not because they have to, but for the sheer enjoyment, which means, ‘nothing except’ enjoyment. Richard uses the word sheer to emphasise how strong and pure this enjoyment is.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: As well as the pleasure of speaking other languages, polyglots are also better at communicating with others. My favourite quote by South Africa’s first black president, Nelson Mandela, is: "If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to him in his language, that goes to his heart."

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How inspiring, Rob – I’m lost for words! Here’s another: ‘To have another language is to possess a second soul’.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So language learning is good for the head, heart and soul – a person’s spirit or the part of them which is believed to continue existing after death.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes – and what’s more, language learning is good for the brain too. That’s according to Harvard neuroscientist, Eve Fedorenko.She’s researched the effects of speaking multiple languages on the brains of growing children.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Eve predicted that multilingual children would have hyperactive language brains. But what she actually found surprised her, as she explains here to BBC World Service’s The Documentary:

transcript.author: Eve Fedorenko
transcript.text: What we found – this is now people who already have proficiency in multiple languages - what we found is that their language regions appear to be smaller, and that was surprising…  and as people get better and better, more automatic at performing the task, the activations shrink, so to speak, over time, it becomes so that you don’t have to use as much brain tissue to do the task as well, so you become more efficient.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Eve was testing children who already have language proficiency – the skill and ability to do something, such as speak a language.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Her surprising discovery was that the language regions of these children’s brains were shrinking – not because their speaking skills were getting worse, but the opposite; as they learned and repeated language patterns, their brain tissue became more efficient – worked quicker and more effectively.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It’s suggested that this increased efficiency is a result of exposure to different languages.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So that proves it, Neil: speaking many languages is good for the head, heart, mind and soul!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You took the words right out of my mouth!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And speaking of words, what does the ‘glot’ in polyglot actually mean? Was my answer correct?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ah, that’s right. In my quiz question I asked you for the meaning of the word ‘polyglot’.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I said, b) many sounds.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But in fact the correct answer was c) many tongues. You may be a polyglot, Rob, but you’re not quite a polymath yet!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, well, let me get my brain tissues working by recapping the vocabulary, starting with polyglot – someone who speaks many languages.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The language centres in a polyglot’s brain are efficient – theywork quickly and effectively in an organised way.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Proficiency means the skill and ability to do something well. And if you identify with something, you feel you are similar or closely connected to it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Polyglots learn languages for the sheer enjoyment of it – a word meaning ‘nothing except‘ which is used to emphasise the strength of feeling.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So speaking many languages is good for mind and soul – a person’s non-physical spirit which some believe to continue after death.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s it for this programme, but to discover more about language learning, including some useful practical tips, check out The Superlinguists series from BBC World Service’s The Documentary!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Bye for now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Bye!
